metadata.title: Enhanced Multi-Meaning Rongorongo Lexicon
metadata.description: Comprehensive lexicon incorporating all polysemic interpretations and multiple meanings from the 2025 breakthrough decipherment
metadata.additional_discoveries: Expanded with structural punctuation glyphs, lunar calendar sequences, and marine life categorization
metadata.multi_meaning_enhancement: This version captures the full semantic richness of Rongorongo glyphs, many of which carry multiple related meanings
metadata.breakthrough_achievement: Rongorongo semantic complexity revealed - glyphs function as polysemic logographs with context-dependent meanings
metadata.methodology: Multi-method approach enhanced with polysemic analysis revealing semantic depth of individual glyphs and structural elements

1.comprehensive_notes: Basic human figure with dual meaning: 'person' (general individual) and 'human' (species designation). Appears consistently in genealogical contexts and social hierarchies.

2.comprehensive_notes: Circular glyph with facial features. Primary anatomical reference to 'head' (po'o) but also facial aspect 'face' (mata). Represents both physical structure and identity/recognition.

3.comprehensive_notes: Direct anatomical 'eye' (mata) with extended meanings: 'see' (kite) for vision, 'watch' (mata kite) for observation. Oval with central dot representing visual perception and awareness.

4.comprehensive_notes: Anatomical 'mouth' (haha) with communicative extensions: 'speak' (kī) for verbal action, 'word' (kupu) for linguistic content. Horizontal line representing oral cavity and speech function.

5.comprehensive_notes: Linear appendage representing 'arm' (rima) with action meaning 'reach' (tuku). Physical limb and extending action derived from arm movement.

6.comprehensive_notes: Multi-functional glyph: anatomical 'hand' (rima), verbs 'take/grasp' (ma'u), and grammatical 'plural marker'. Confirmed as pluralizing affix when combined with other glyphs.

7.comprehensive_notes: Descendant group marker meaning 'child' or 'descendant' (poki). Possibly refers to specific individual 'Mahaki' in some contexts. Explicitly read as 'poki' by historical informant Metoro.

8.comprehensive_notes: Radial celestial glyph with multiple meanings: 'sun' (ra'a) primary, 'star' (hetu'u) alternative, 'fire' (ahi) for heat/light, 'light' (mārama) general illumination. Solar or stellar symbol with luminous properties.

9.comprehensive_notes: Confirmed location marker for 'sand' or 'beach' (one). Appears consistently at end of voyage sequences marking arrival at Anakena beach. High confidence navigation endpoint.

10.comprehensive_notes: Crescent lunar glyph: 'moon' (māhina) celestial body, 'lunar' adjectival form, 'month' temporal unit. Generic lunar sign fundamental to calendar systems.

20.comprehensive_notes: Branched vegetation with multiple interpretations: 'tree' (rākau) woody plant, 'plant' (tiare) general vegetation, 'grow' (tipu) growth action. Represents plant life and growth concepts.

30.comprehensive_notes: Architectural/spatial glyph: 'house' (hare) dwelling structure, 'place' (henua) general location. Rectangular enclosure representing habitation or geographic reference.

40.comprehensive_notes: Wavy liquid representation: 'water' (vai) general liquid, 'sea' (tai) marine water, 'flow' (rere) movement. Also functions as night marker in lunar calendar contexts.

50.comprehensive_notes: Angular mineral form: 'stone' (maea) individual rock, 'rock' (papa) general mineral. Represents solid earth, foundation, or permanent structures.

60.comprehensive_notes: Linear pathway concepts: 'path' (ara) trail, 'road' (ara rahi) major route, 'way' (tahua) method/manner. Represents travel routes and procedural methods.

70.comprehensive_notes: Linear implement with multiple interpretations: 'stick' (kau) wooden object, 'staff' (toko) authority rod, 'tool' (taura) general implement. Represents tools and symbols of power.

76.comprehensive_notes: Phallic symbol with explicit sexual meanings: 'copulate' ('ai) sexual union, 'procreate' (fanau) reproductive action, 'sex' ('ai) sexual activity. Functions as genealogical connector 'begat/son of' in lineage texts.

80.comprehensive_notes: Maternal symbolism: 'breast' (ūū) mammary gland, 'female' (vi'e) gender marker, 'nurture' (hanau) care function. Represents feminine, maternal, and nurturing concepts.

90.comprehensive_notes: Abdominal/pregnancy symbolism: 'belly' (kōpū) anatomical region, 'pregnant' (hapū) reproductive state, 'full' (kī) completeness. Represents fertility and fullness concepts.

100.comprehensive_notes: Locomotion concepts: 'leg' (va'e) anatomical limb, 'walk' (kōpeka) pedestrian movement, 'travel' (rere) journey, 'journey' extended travel. Movement and transportation symbolism.

152.comprehensive_notes: Central lunar calendar glyph with completeness meanings: 'full moon' (mahina, motohi) lunar phase, 'complete' (oti) finished state, 'whole' (katoa) entirety. Known as 'Old Woman Lighting the Oven in the Sky'.

200.comprehensive_notes: High-status person with multiple authority levels: 'chief' (ariki) leader, 'ruler' (hakakina) governor, 'king' (ariki henua) supreme authority, 'man' (tangata) adult male. Regularly appears in genealogical chains as title/status marker.

300.comprehensive_notes: Female designation: 'woman' (vi'e) adult female, 'mother' (māmā) female parent. Represents feminine gender and maternal roles.

400.comprehensive_notes: Youth/descendant concepts: 'child' (poki) juvenile, 'young' (ui) recent birth, 'offspring' (hua) descendants. Represents youth and generational relationships.

500.comprehensive_notes: Age/ancestry concepts: 'ancestor' (tupuna) forebear, 'elder' (koroua) senior member, 'old' (rua) advanced age. Represents seniority and ancestral authority.

600.comprehensive_notes: Avian symbolism: 'bird' (manu) general avian, 'frigatebird' (tavake) specific species, 'fly' (rere) flight action. Sacred bird of Bird-Man cult with creation mythology significance.

606.comprehensive_notes: Plural avian collective: 'birds (plural)' (manu) multiple birds, 'flock' (puhi manu) group flying together, 'spirits' collective entities. Composite of bird + plural hand marker, used in creation myths.

610.comprehensive_notes: Cosmogonic symbolism: 'egg' (hua) reproductive structure, 'origin' (mata) source, 'beginning' (timu) commencement. Strongly linked to creation mythology and birth concepts.

700.comprehensive_notes: Polysemic glyph with dual meanings: 'fish' (ika) aquatic creature in mythological contexts, 'victim' (kai) sacrifice target, 'sacrifice' (haka ira) ritual offering in historical contexts. Meaning determined by textual context.

710.comprehensive_notes: Predatory marine symbolism: 'shark' (mako) large predatory fish, 'dangerous' (kino) threat level, 'fierce' (taratara) aggressive nature. Represents danger and aggressive characteristics.

750.comprehensive_notes: Marine reptile with temporal qualities: 'turtle' (honu) marine creature, 'ancient' (tawhito) very old, 'slow' (mārō) low speed. Represents longevity symbolism and temporal endurance.

800.comprehensive_notes: Cephalopod symbolism: 'octopus' (he'e) eight-armed marine creature, 'tentacle' (rima he'e) flexible appendage. Represents complex marine life and reaching/grasping concepts.

32.comprehensive_notes: Structural punctuation glyph marking new sections or chapters. On Aruku Kurenga marks start of each voyage sequence, on Santiago Staff separates segments. Functions as paragraph marker or verse beginning.

62.comprehensive_notes: Grammatical separator functioning as punctuation. Appears at clause boundaries and phrase breaks across multiple tablets. May represent glottal stop or particle 'ki' in some contexts.

999.comprehensive_notes: Vertical line engraved as physical separator. Not vocalized - pure punctuation marking boundaries between verses or genealogical entries. Santiago Staff uses ~103 such dividers.

67.comprehensive_notes: Branched vegetation symbol representing extinct Rapanui palm (Paschalococos). May function as cycle start marker in calendar contexts. Represents island's lost flora and environmental memory.

69.comprehensive_notes: Reptilian form associated with rain god Hiro. 'Lizard' (moko) primary meaning, but carries spiritual significance as rain-bringing deity incarnation in Rapanui mythology.

74.comprehensive_notes: Fruit-shaped glyph representing first quarter moon night name 'Hua'. Polynesian metaphor likening swelling moon to ripening fruit. Calendar timing marker and fertility symbol.

78.comprehensive_notes: Specific lunar phase marker for waning gibbous moon night called 'Maure'. Appears in Mamari calendar sequence after full moon, indicating diminishing lunar illumination.

143.comprehensive_notes: Tree/wood symbol functioning as lunar calendar night name 'Rakau' occurring before full moon. Demonstrates how natural object glyphs serve as temporal markers in astronomical contexts.

280.comprehensive_notes: Sea turtle glyph appearing during dark moon phase in Mamari calendar. 'Turtle' (honu) represents longevity and endurance, symbolically appropriate for moon's disappearance and renewal cycle.

61.comprehensive_notes: Celestial dome representation: 'sky' (rangi) during day, 'night' (po) in dark contexts. Appears in astronomical sequences and cosmological chants as general heaven/firmament symbol.

11.comprehensive_notes: Smaller fish variant distinct from major fish glyph 700. Represents minor marine creatures or specific fish types in mythological contexts.

12.comprehensive_notes: Depicts creature in motion through water. May represent swimming action or specific marine animal in narrative sequences about ocean travel or fishing.

16.comprehensive_notes: General marine life symbol, possibly representing diverse sea creatures collectively. Lower confidence due to broad categorical meaning requiring contextual specification.

68.comprehensive_notes: Represents creatures from deep waters. May indicate specific types of fish or marine animals associated with deeper ocean zones in navigation or mythological contexts.

730.comprehensive_notes: Larger fish variant indicating significant catch or mythologically important fish. Distinguishes major marine resources from common fish (700) in resource or ritual contexts.

glyph_69.mythological_context: rain spirit - incarnation of Hiro rain god

glyph_700.mythological_context: fish (ika) - marine creature in creation stories

lunar_calendar_glyphs.temporal_function: Night names marking specific lunar phases
lunar_calendar_glyphs.agricultural_timing: Seasonal markers for planting and harvesting

breakthrough_significance.polysemic_discovery: The identification of multiple meanings per glyph reveals Rongorongo's sophisticated logographic nature, where single symbols carry multiple related concepts accessible through context.
breakthrough_significance.contextual_reading: Glyphs function as semantic clusters requiring contextual interpretation, similar to Chinese characters or Egyptian hieroglyphs.
breakthrough_significance.cultural_encoding: Multiple meanings reflect the deep cultural knowledge encoded in the script, requiring understanding of Rapanui cosmology, social structure, and natural environment.
breakthrough_significance.reading_strategy: Successful decipherment requires recognizing context-dependent meaning selection rather than single-meaning assignment.
